articles.headline: Labor Board Challenges Secrecy in Wall Street Contracts
articles.snippet: The National Labor Relations Board has challenged some parts of the employee contracts at the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates, including the confidentiality agreement.
articles.abstract: The National Labor Relations Board has challenged some parts of the employee contracts at the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates, including the confidentiality agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, moneymaking companies have long relied on confidentiality agreements to prevent employees from divulging their secrets.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Showing Confidence, Hillary Clinton Pushes Into Republican Strongholds
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton hopes to extend her edge over Donald J. Trump and help other Democrats in what party leaders think could become an election that swamps Republicans at every level.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton hopes to extend her edge over Donald J. Trump and help other Democrats in what party leaders think could become an election that swamps Republicans at every level.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign is planning its most ambitious push yet into traditionally right-leaning states, a new offensive aimed at extending her growing advantage over Donald J. Trump while bolstering down-ballot candidates in what party leaders increasingly suggest could be a sweeping victory for Democrats at every level.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Haitians, Battered by Hurricane, Huddle in Caves: ‘This Is the Only Shelter We Have’
articles.snippet: “It is our house that God created when we most needed it,” said one of the hundreds of villagers who fled into caves as Hurricane Matthew destroyed their homes.
articles.abstract: “It is our house that God created when we most needed it,” said one of the hundreds of villagers who fled into caves as Hurricane Matthew destroyed their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LACADONIE, Haiti — When the rain comes at night in these distant mountains, the people flee what homes they have left. They race down hills threaded with stones and ragged palm branches, the earth the color of rust.

articles.headline: Dalian Wanda of China Offers a Carrot to Hollywood
articles.snippet: The Chinese conglomerate wants to be an entertainment superpower, and it would like to start by getting more American movies made in China.
articles.abstract: The Chinese conglomerate wants to be an entertainment superpower, and it would like to start by getting more American movies made in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Wang Jianlin, chairman of the Dalian Wanda Group, the Chinese conglomerate that is emerging — controversially — as a superpower in the entertainment business, sat in an opulent armchair at the Peninsula Hotel here on Sunday and discussed his business ventures with a casual efficiency.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ May Hurt Britain Where It Thrives: Science and Research
articles.snippet: Though nothing has changed since Britain voted to leave the European Union, the worries of Britain’s scientists mirror concerns in the business community.
articles.abstract: Though nothing has changed since Britain voted to leave the European Union, the worries of Britain’s scientists mirror concerns in the business community.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Adam Durant started his company analyzing climate-related threats to aircraft, he and his team of researchers symbolized the possibilities offered by the European Union.

articles.headline: Could a President Clinton Be Tough on Wall St.? Her Staff’s Emails Hint Yes
articles.snippet: Some of Hillary Clinton’s detractors spread the view that Wall Street owns her, but the WikiLeaks documents point to a different dynamic if readers look closer at messages among her staff.
articles.abstract: Some of Hillary Clinton’s detractors spread the view that Wall Street owns her, but the WikiLeaks documents point to a different dynamic if readers look closer at messages among her staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton was battling Bernie Sanders for the Democratic presidential nomination, she made spirited attacks on Wall Street and corporate America.

articles.headline: Agencies Clashed on Classification of Clinton Email, Inquiry Shows
articles.snippet: Newly released documents include discussion of a possible “quid pro quo” to settle a dispute between the State Department and the F.B.I. over the classification of one of Mrs. Clinton’s emails.
articles.abstract: Newly released documents include discussion of a possible “quid pro quo” to settle a dispute between the State Department and the F.B.I. over the classification of one of Mrs. Clinton’s emails.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Documents released Monday in the Hillary Clinton email investigation show intense disagreement last year between the State Department and the F.B.I. over whether some of Mrs. Clinton’s emails should be considered classified, including a discussion of a possible “quid pro quo” to settle one dispute.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Battle for Mosul Tests Obama Strategy to Shift Fight’s Burden From U.S.
articles.snippet: The administration’s counterterrorism doctrine aims to spread military responsibilities to regional partners rather than have the United States act alone.
articles.abstract: The administration’s counterterrorism doctrine aims to spread military responsibilities to regional partners rather than have the United States act alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Iraqi forces launch their long-awaited campaign to retake the city of Mosul from the Islamic State, President Obama’s doctrine of aiding other countries militarily rather than leading every fight is facing its greatest test yet.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Global Governments, Loath to Change, Are Wasting Oil With Subsidies
articles.snippet: From South America to the Middle East, leaders are clinging to energy subsidies that negatively impact the environment, despite an economic rebound and cheap oil.
articles.abstract: From South America to the Middle East, leaders are clinging to energy subsidies that negatively impact the environment, despite an economic rebound and cheap oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Venezuela has no shortage of problems, but one of the more curious is its cheap prices at the gas pump.

articles.headline: As China Shifts From Exporter to Importer, Fortunes Change
articles.snippet: The country’s energy sector has gone through a major reshaping, perhaps nowhere more so than in the city of Daqing, home to China’s biggest oil field.
articles.abstract: The country’s energy sector has gone through a major reshaping, perhaps nowhere more so than in the city of Daqing, home to China’s biggest oil field.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Zhou Bo was a born oilman.
articles.byline: By Owen Guo and Neil Gough

articles.headline: Samsung’s Uneven Handling of Galaxy Note 7 Fires Angers Chinese
articles.snippet: The company’s decision to exclude China from an initial recall has prompted a backlash that could further erode its position in the important market.
articles.abstract: The company’s decision to exclude China from an initial recall has prompted a backlash that could further erode its position in the important market.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Zhang Sitong was saving a friend’s phone number on his Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphone when it started to vibrate and smoke. He threw it on the ground and told his friend to start filming.

articles.headline: After Losses in Syria and Iraq, ISIS Moves the Goal Posts
articles.snippet: The group has been laying ideological groundwork to maintain its appeal as it suffers on the battlefield.
articles.abstract: The group has been laying ideological groundwork to maintain its appeal as it suffers on the battlefield.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State leaders had long promised their followers an apocalyptic battle — foretold, some believe, by the Prophet Muhammad — in an otherwise nondescript village they controlled in northern Syria.

articles.headline: Ecuador Cuts Internet of Julian Assange, WikiLeaks’ Founder
articles.snippet: The country made it clear it feared it was being sucked into an effort to “interfere in electoral processes” in the United States.
articles.abstract: The country made it clear it feared it was being sucked into an effort to “interfere in electoral processes” in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ecuador said Tuesday that it had cut off Julian Assange’s access to the internet in his exile in the country’s London embassy, making clear that it feared being sucked into an effort to “interfere in electoral processes” in the United States by the activities of the WikiLeaks founder.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Guiding Refugees in Europe on a Rocky Path to Assimilation
articles.snippet: Private groups have sprung up to help newcomers find professional networks and improve their skills, but the adjustment has been harder than expected.
articles.abstract: Private groups have sprung up to help newcomers find professional networks and improve their skills, but the adjustment has been harder than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Mahmoud al-Omar leaned over a sewing machine in the basement of a former prison being used to house refugees and began stitching jeans for a popular clothing line. With more than 15 years experience as a tailor in Syria, he zipped through one pair and moved on to another, methodically filling a small order.
